question: Why can hardness, streak, and cleavage be used to identify minerals?

content.source_1: Hardness, streak, and cleavage are standard diagnostic physical properties used in hand-specimen mineral identification.
content.source_2: Within a given mineral species, these properties are generally consistent across samples when measured properly (for example, quartz consistently shows Mohs hardness ~7, no cleavage, and a white streak).
content.source_3: Different mineral species usually differ in at least one of these properties, which allows field keys to separate most minerals by hardness, streak, and cleavage.
content.source_4: Distinct minerals can share the same hardness, streak, and similar cleavage; for instance, orthoclase and plagioclase feldspars both have Mohs hardness around 6, white streaks, and two cleavages near 90Â°, making them difficult to distinguish by those three tests alone.
content.source_5: Test results can be ambiguous in practice: many minerals harder than a porcelain streak plate yield a white or no streak, cleavage may be obscured in weathered or fine-grained specimens, and some minerals show hardness anisotropy (e.g., kyanite is much harder in one direction than another).
content.source_6: Because overlaps and ambiguities occur, definitive mineral identification often relies on additional evidence beyond these properties (e.g., acid reaction for carbonates, optical microscopy, or X-ray diffraction).
